G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, given Plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk Superior Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County at the Premises located at 123 Ocean Ave, Quincy, MA 02169, and Defendant transacts business in Norfolk County.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is located in, conducts substantial business in, and/or maintains the Premises in Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this lawsuit occurred there.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about. See, e.g., Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–709 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372–373 (2010).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard actually abolished the traditional invitee/licensee distinction for premises liability in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors, rather than grounding the duty on the plaintiff’s status as a business invitee. The quoted portion from Kaplan, J.’s concurrence critiques status-based classifications; it does not affirm that a ‘business invitee’ category controls the defendant’s duty as stated in the proposition. Thus, the case does not support the proposition as phrased, which relies on the now-rejected invitee framework.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about. See, e.g., Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–709 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372–373 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional duty owed to invitees: to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to repair, remove, or warn of dangerous conditions the owner knew or reasonably should have known about. Although the plaintiff here is a shopper (a business invitee), the court restates this general invitee standard drawing on Mounsey and earlier cases. That language directly supports the proposition about a business invitee and the landowner’s duty of reasonable care, including warning of known or reasonably knowable dangers.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: If the plaintiff was an invitee, defined as a person invited onto the property by the property owner for the property owner’s benefit, the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 785–789 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Alternatively, Defendant had constructive knowledge of the dangerous condition because the Spill was created by Defendant’s own employee in the course of her work, and the hazardous condition remained on the floor for at least approximately ten (10) minutes without being remedied, during which time multiple employees traversed the area and avoided the puddle.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns constructive knowledge based on (1) a spill allegedly created by the defendant’s employee and (2) the hazardous condition remaining for about ten minutes with employees traversing and avoiding it. Sheehan does not address an employee-created spill or a specific time-on-the-floor theory. Instead, it replaces the traditional actual/constructive notice requirement with the ‘mode of operation’ doctrine in self-service stores, allowing notice to be inferred from the nature of the operation, not from proof that the condition existed for a certain period or was created by an employee. Thus, it does not support the particular constructive-notice theory stated in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove a grocery store caused a substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the store operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition… Of the two modern approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.”

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a person or entity that owns, occupies, or controls property owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including likelihood of injury, probable seriousness of injury, and burden of avoiding the risk.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring passage deals only with the procedural posture of the case and the continued use (or abrogation) of the “hidden defect” rule in premises liability. It does not set out or adopt the broader common-law duty standard toward all lawful entrants, nor does it discuss the likelihood/seriousness/burden factors referenced in the proposition. Any such duty language must appear elsewhere in the majority opinion, not in the excerpt provided, so this specific text does not support the claimed proposition.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.relevant_excerpt: This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. … However, the court has chosen to go beyond that and has declared, for the reasons discussed in part 4 of the opinion, that the “hidden defect” rule “no longer is to be applied in cases involving tort actions against landowners.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–265 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Where a defect or hazard is created by the defendant or its employees, Massachusetts law permits the factfinder to infer notice from the defendant’s own conduct, and explicit proof of the length of time the danger existed is not required.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss notice, but only in the context where there is *no* evidence that the hazard was created by the defendant or its employees. The court holds that in such circumstances the plaintiff must prove the condition existed long enough for constructive notice; it does not state or apply any rule that notice may be inferred from the defendant’s own creation of the hazard without proof of duration. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed, which concerns hazards created by the defendant or its employees.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 682–685 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: Because Defendant, through its employee, created the dangerous condition, Defendant had actual notice of the hazard and a heightened duty to act reasonably to eliminate the risk or adequately warn invitees.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not say that when the defendant or its employee creates the dangerous condition, the defendant thereby has actual notice and a *heightened* duty to eliminate or warn of the hazard. Rather, Sarkisian distinguishes between conditions created by the owner (where traditional notice rules already apply) and conditions created by third-party interference, for which the mode of operation doctrine modifies only the *notice* requirement. The case reiterates the ordinary Restatement § 343 duty of reasonable care; it does not impose a heightened duty tied to owner-created hazards.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Where the condition consists of spillage on the floor of a place of business, the first element is satisfied if the operator of that business ‘caused [the] substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the ... operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the . . . operator should have been aware of the condition.’ Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 782-783.… As the court explained, the mode of operation approach is superfluous where the defendant, rather than a third party, affirmatively causes the unsafe condition.”

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 166–167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: Defendant’s conduct in leaving water and ice on the tile floor in a narrow hallway, without any warning, after actual knowledge of the Spill, fell below the standard of care of a reasonably prudent restaurant owner or operator under similar circumstances.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The case involves a fall on a subway stairway caused by an unidentified foreign substance, not water and ice in a restaurant hallway. The opinion addresses the general duty of a premises owner to use due care and the evidentiary requirements to infer negligence from the presence of a foreign substance and the time element. It does not involve a defendant with actual knowledge of a specific spill or failure to warn after such knowledge, nor does it discuss the standard of care for restaurant owners under those circumstances. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know… Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance.”

Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.raw_text: Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874, 883 (1978)
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct in leaving water and ice on the tile floor in a narrow hallway, without any warning, after actual knowledge of the Spill, fell below the standard of care of a reasonably prudent restaurant owner or operator under similar circumstances.
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent design of a refuse truck compactor and related duty-to-warn and assumption-of-risk issues in products liability. It does not address premises liability, restaurant owners, or the standard of care for handling water or ice spills on floors. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about a restaurant owner’s negligence in leaving water and ice on a tile floor without warning.
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.relevant_excerpt: "In our view the focus in design negligence cases is not on how the product is meant to function, but on whether the product is designed with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers.... We decline to hold that there can be no negligence in design if the product performs as intended, or if there are warnings found to be adequate, or if the dangers are obvious."

Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 475 Mass.raw_text: Bowers v. P. Wile’s, Inc., 475 Mass. 34, 41–44 (2016)
Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 475 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law does not require Plaintiff to prove the exact fraction of time the dangerous condition existed where, as here, Defendant’s own employee created the condition and there is direct and circumstantial evidence of knowledge and inaction.
Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 475 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss that, under the traditional approach, a plaintiff normally must show how long a transitory hazard existed, but here the court applies the alternative “mode of operation” doctrine to relieve the plaintiff of that burden where customer activity foreseeably creates recurring hazards. The case does not involve a condition created by the defendant’s own employee and does not stand for a general rule that a plaintiff need not prove the duration of the hazard whenever the defendant’s employee created it and there is evidence of knowledge and inaction. Its holding is specifically about substituting mode‑of‑operation foreseeability for traditional notice requirements, not about employee‑created conditions per se.
Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 475 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, a plaintiff can establish that a business had actual or constructive notice of a temporary hazard. Constructive notice can be established by evidence indicating the length of time the hazard was on the walkway. … Bowers … does not suggest that she has any knowledge of how long the stone was on the walkway. Accordingly, under the traditional theory of premises liability, Bowers cannot establish Agway's actual or constructive knowledge… Bowers argues, however, that her claim should be viewed under the mode of operation approach…”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Defendant also failed to warn Plaintiff of the hidden danger, despite having actual knowledge of the Spill and its slippery nature, and despite knowing that patrons, including Plaintiff, would use the hallway to access the restroom.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s failure to warn of a hidden spill hazard in a hallway, despite actual knowledge and foreseeability of patron use. Dos Santos involves a residential landowner’s duty regarding an open and obvious trampoline–pool configuration and focuses on the duty to remedy an open and obvious danger, not on failure to warn of a hidden condition like a spill in a hallway. The opinion expressly notes that for open and obvious dangers the duty to warn is negated, and the case deals with design/maintenance of a recreational setup, not with warning duties about concealed slip hazards to business patrons.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “However, ‘[l]andowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises because it is not reasonably foreseeable that a visitor exercising (as the law presumes) reasonable care for his own safety would suffer injury from such blatant hazards.’ O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204, 211 (2000)… A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg….”

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–106 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable to Defendant that leaving water and ice on the floor in a high-traffic hallway without cleaning or warning would result in a patron slipping, falling, and suffering bodily injuries.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns unsecured forklifts and the foreseeability that an intoxicated seaman would operate one and injure a visitor; it does not involve a slip-and-fall, water or ice on a floor, or a failure to clean or warn about such a condition. While the opinion discusses foreseeability of harm to persons lawfully on the premises, its holding is specifically about negligent failure to secure a dangerous machine, not about premises liability for liquid on a floor. Using this case to support the stated slip-and-fall proposition would therefore be inaccurate.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area…”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were within the scope of the foreseeable risk created by Defendant’s negligent failure to remedy or warn about the Spill, and there was no intervening, superseding cause as a matter of law.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Jupin v. Kask deals with duty and foreseeability in the context of negligent storage of firearms, not with whether a plaintiff’s injuries fall within the scope of the foreseeable risk in a premises-liability "spill" scenario or whether an intervening, superseding cause exists as a matter of law. The court expressly leaves causation issues, including the effect of the shooter’s criminal act, to the jury and does not hold there was no intervening superseding cause as a matter of law. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition about scope of risk and superseding cause regarding a spill.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.relevant_excerpt: "We generally consider the latter three questions — whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendant’s breach and the damage were causally related — to be the special province of the jury. ... In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property, and that Kask thus owed the officer a duty of reasonable care. We agree that there was a duty of reasonable care in this case..."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any negligence is attributed to Plaintiff— which she denies—any such negligence was substantially less than that of Defendant, and Plaintiff’s recovery is therefore not barred under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on the damages awarded from the date this action is commenced.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Pursuant to applicable law, including G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C, Plaintiff is entitled to post‑judgment interest, and to taxable costs as allowed by law and rule.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including filing fees and other taxable costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;
